revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Duccio maesta1021.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=300px | title=Maestà | artist=[[Duccio|Duccio di Buoninsegna]] | year=1308–1311 | type=[[Tempera|Tempera and gold on wood]] | height_metric=213 | width_metric=396 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Siena]] | museum=[[Museo dell'Opera Metropolitana del Duomo]] }} The '''''Maestà''''', or '''''Maestà of Duccio''''' is an [[altarpiece]] composed of many individual paintings commissioned by the city of [[Siena]] in 1308 from the artist [[Duccio|Duccio di Buoninsegna]].''Medieval Italy: An Encyclopedia'' by Christopher Kleinhenz (Nov 2003) [[Routledge]], {{ISBN|0415939305}} page 310 The front panels make up a large enthroned [[Madonna (art)|Madonna and Child]] with saints and angels, and a [[predella]] of the ''Childhood of Christ'' with prophets. The reverse has the rest of a combined cycle of the ''[[Life of the Virgin]]'' and the ''[[Life of Christ]]'' in a total of forty-three small scenes; several panels are now dispersed or lost. The base of the panel has an inscription that reads (in translation): "Holy Mother of God, be thou the cause of peace for Siena and life to Duccio because he painted thee thus." "Art History: Fourteenth to Seventeenth Century Art" by Marilyn Stokstad (2011) page 543 Though it took a generation for its effect truly to be felt, Duccio's ''Maestà'' set Italian painting on a course leading away from the hieratic representations of [[Byzantine art]] towards more direct presentations of reality. ==History== The painting was installed in the [[cathedral of Siena]] on 9 June 1311. One person who witnessed this event wrote:
And on that day when it was brought into the cathedral, all workshops remained closed, and the bishop commanded a great host of devoted priests and monks to file past in solemn procession. This was accompanied by all the high officers of the Commune and by all the people; all honorable citizens of Siena surrounded said panel with candles held in their hands, and women and children followed humbly behind. They accompanied the panel amidst the glorious pealing of bells after a solemn procession on the [[Piazza del Campo]] into the very cathedral; and all this out of reverence for the costly panel… The poor received many alms, and we prayed to the Holy Mother of God, our patron saint, that she might in her infinite mercy preserve this our city of Siena from every misfortune, traitor or enemy.
Besides the Virgin Mary and the Baby Jesus, saints depicted in the painting include [[John the Evangelist]] (to the left of the throne); [[Paul of Tarsus|Saint Paul]]; [[Catherine of Alexandria]]; [[John the Baptist]] (to the right of the throne); [[Saint Peter]]; and [[Saint Agnes]].[http://www.abcgallery.com/D/duccio/maesta.html The Maestà by Duccio di Buoninsegna – Olga's Gallery] In the foreground are Siena’s various [[patron saints]]: [[Saint Ansanus]]; [[Sabinus of Spoleto|Saint Sabinus]]; [[Crescentius of Rome|Saint Crescentius]]; and [[Victor and Corona|Saint Victor]]. Creating this altarpiece assembled from many wood panels bonded together before painting was an arduous undertaking. The work was not only large, the central panel was 7 by 13 feet, but it had to be painted on both sides since it could be seen from all directions when installed on the main altar at the centre of the sanctuary.Stockstad, Marilyn. ''Art History'', 2011, 4th ed., {{ISBN|0-205-79094-1}} The altarpiece remained in place until 1711, when it was dismantled in order to distribute the pieces between two altars. The five-metre high construction was dismantled and sawn up, and the paintings damaged in the process. Partial restoration took place in 1956. The dismantling also led to pieces going astray, either being sold, or simply unaccounted for. Extant remains of the altarpiece not at Siena are divided among several other museums. ==Stylistic analysis== *Deposition Christ's followers, Joseph and John, remove him from the cross while Nicodemus removes nails from his feet. The Virgin Mary looks into his closed eyes while Mary Magdalene holds his arm, and you can see the painful expression in everyone’s eyes as they tend to the dead Christ. The background has the same gold texture as in the "Crucifixion" and the cross that held Christ has blood running onto the ground, increasing the sense of realism in the scene. This panel aroused the emotions of its audiences and the story helped to symbolize the birth of Christianity. *Burial Immediately following the "Deposition," is the depiction of Christ as he is prepared for burial, surrounded by his mourning followers. His mother leans in close to him and kisses him one last time and Mary Magdalene throws her arms towards the sky in anguish. The background retains the gold setting of the "Deposition" and "Crucifixion," and the mountains in the background are similar to the mountains portrayed in previous and subsequent panels. These mountains lead the viewer’s eye to Mary who is accompanying him, and then to Christ’s face. This scene also elicits an intense emotional response from its viewers and you can see the close connection that the burial party has to Christ, and especially to the Virgin Mary. ==List of panels== ===In Siena=== [[File:Maest 0 duccio 1308-11 siena duomo.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Front]] [[File:Maest 001 duccio siena duomo.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Reverse]] *''The Mother of God Enthroned with the Christ Child Amidst Angels and Saints'', central panel *''The Wedding Feast of Cana'' *''The Temptation of Christ atop the Temple'' *''The Annunciation of the Virgin's death'' *''The Virgin's Farewell to St. John'' *''The Virgin's Farewell to the Apostles'' *''The Death of the Virgin'' *''The Funeral of the Virgin'' *''The Burial of the Virgin'' *''The Appearance of Christ behind closed doors'' *''The Incredulity of St. Thomas'' *''The Pentecost'' *''The Appearance of Christ on Lake Tiberias'' *''The Appearance of Christ on the Mountain in Galilee'' *''The Appearance of Christ to the Apostles at Supper'' *''The Adoration of the Magi; Solomon'' *''The Presentation in the Temple; the prophet Malachi'' *''The Massacre of the Innocents; the prophet Jeremiah'' *''The Flight into Egypt; the prophet Hosea'' *''The Boy Jesus among the Doctors'' *''Episodes from Christ's Passion'' Tempera and gold on wood. The work, consisting of 26 episodes on 14 panels, was originally the reverse surface of the ''Maestà''. ===Elsewhere=== *''Angel'' (formerly in the [[Stoclet Palace|Stoclet]] Collection, [[Brussels]]) *''Angel'' ([[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], [[Philadelphia]]) *''Archangel Gabriel'' (Castel [[Huis Bergh]], in [['s-Heerenberg]], The Netherlands) *''Angel'' ([[Mount Holyoke College]], [[South Hadley, Massachusetts]]) *''The Coronation of the Virgin'' (Szépmüveszéti Muzeum, [[Budapest]] – [https://www.flickr.com/photos/mymuk/5113825724/ image]) *''The Annunciation'' ([[National Gallery, London]]) *''Isaiah; Nativity; Ezekiel'' (Andrew W. Mellon Collection, [[National Gallery of Art]], Washington, DC) *''Temptation of Christ on the Mountain'' ([[Frick Collection]], New York) *''Calling of SS. Peter and Andrew'' (Samuel H. Kress Collection, National Gallery of Art, Washington DC) *''Christ and the Samaritan Woman'' ([[Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza]], Madrid) *''Healing of the Blind Man'' (National Gallery, London) *''The Transfiguration'' (National Gallery, London) *''The Raising of Lazarus'' ([[Kimbell Art Museum]], [[Fort Worth]], Texas) ==See also== * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] ==References== {| align="right" style="border: 1px solid #aaa; width: 100px;" | align="right"|[[File:Christ Taken Prisoner.jpg|210px]] {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | video1 = [http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/duccio-and-siena.html Duccio's ''Maesta'' (front)], [[Smarthistory]]{{cite web | title =Duccio's Maesta (front) | work = | publisher =[[Smarthistory]] at [[Khan Academy]]| date = | url =http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/duccio-and-siena.html | accessdate =31 January 2013 }} | video2 = [http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/duccios-maesta.html Duccio's ''Maesta'' (back)], [[Smarthistory]]{{cite web | title =Duccio's Maesta (back) | work = | publisher =[[Smarthistory]] at [[Khan Academy]]| date = | url =http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/duccios-maesta.html | accessdate =24 January 2013 }} }} |} {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|last=Bellosi |first=Luciano|year=1999 |title=Duccio: The Maestà |location=New York |publisher=Thames and Hudson|isbn=9780500237717}} *{{cite book|first=Giovanna |last=Ragioneri|title=Duccio|location=Florence|publisher=Cantini|year=1989 |isbn=88-7737-058-0 }} https://www.britannica.com/topic/Maesta-altarpiece-by-Duccio ==External links== {{Commons category|Cathedral (Siena) - Maestà}} *[http://www.abcgallery.com/D/duccio/maesta.html Article giving diagrams of the structure and images of the pieces] {{DEFAULTSORT:Maesta (Duccio)}} [[Category:Paintings by Duccio]] [[Category:1300s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Madonna and Child]] [[Category:Christian art]] [[Category:Christian iconography]] [[Category:Paintings depicting John the Baptist]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Paul the Apostle]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Saint Peter]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category: Paintings on gold backgrounds]] [[Category:Polyptychs]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Meta | logo = [[File:Meta Logo Black.svg|300px|center|Meta Inc. Logo]] | trading_name = <!-- d/b/a/, doing business as - if different from legal name above --> | native_name = <!-- Company's name in home country language --> | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-2 code, e.g. "fr" for French. If there is more than one native name, in different languages, enter those names using {{tl|lang}}, instead. --> | romanized = | former type = | services = Scientific knowledge network powered by machine intelligence | traded_as = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = 2009<!-- City, Country ({{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}}) --> | founders = Sam Molyneux, Amy Molyneux | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | location_country = | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices &c. --> | area_served = [[Academia]], [[Government]], [[Publishing]], [[Industry]] | key_people = | products = | production = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 25-35 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|Meta.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Meta''' is a company performing [[big data]] analysis of [[scientific literature]]. Company is headquartered in Redwood City, California<ref name=sfjournal>{{citation|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2017/01/25/chan-zuckerberg-lease-redwood-city-lane-partners.html|title=Chan Zuckerberg Initiative signs lease in Lane Partners' new Redwood City building|publisher=San Francisco Business Times|date=January 25, 2017|accessdate=October 31, 2018}}</ref> (formerly [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada<ref name=one>{{citation|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/16/sciencescape-wants-to-solve-academic-research-discoverability-deal-with-the-noise-problem/|title=Sciencescape Wants To Solve Academic Research Discoverability, Deal With The Noise Problem|publisher=TechCrunch|author=Darrell Etherington|date=June 16, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref>) and operates Meta Science, a literature discovery platform.<ref name=two>{{citation|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2013-06/17/sciencescape |title=Sciencescape aims to sift through snowballing science research|publisher=Wired.co.uk|author=|date=|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name=three>{{citation|url=http://www.itbusiness.ca/news/sciencescape-cataloguing-research-papers-everywhere-one-essay-at-a-time/36336|title=Sciencescape cataloguing research papers everywhere, one essay at a time|publisher=itbusiness.ca|author=Candice So |date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name=four>{{citation|url=http://marscommons.marsdd.com/the-data-visualizers/sciencescape|title=The Data Visualizers|publisher=MaRS Commons Magazine|author=|date=|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref> The company was acquired by the [[Chan Zuckerberg Initiative]] in 2017.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/01/23/chan-zuckerberg-initiative-meta/|title=Chan Zuckerberg Initiative acquires and will free up science search engine Meta – TechCrunch |website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
==History==
Meta Inc., formerly Sciencescape Inc.,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Meta Launches Universal Machine Intelligence Platform to Unite the Fragmented Scientific Information Ecosystem|url = http://www.marketwatch.com/story/meta-launches-universal-machine-intelligence-platform-to-unite-the-fragmented-scientific-information-ecosystem-2015-11-03|website = MarketWatch |date=November 3, 2015 |accessdate = May 8, 2018}}</ref> was founded in 2010 by Sam and Amy Molyneux. Before co-founding Meta, Sam Molyneux studied [[cancer genomics]] at the [[Ontario Cancer Institute]] at [[Princess Margaret Cancer Centre|Princess Margaret Hospital]] in Toronto.<ref name=four /><ref name=nine /> The service was developed with the intention of curating the millions of articles in the area of academic publishing.<ref name=one /><ref name=two /><ref name=three /><ref name=nine /><ref name=seven /><ref name=eight />
As of September 2016, Meta has analyzed over 26 million papers and profiled 14 million researchers.<ref name=eleven>{{citation|url=http://meta.com/about|title=About Meta|publisher=Meta|date=September 13, 2016|accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> The company has struck deals with publishers in science, technology and mathematics fields, which give the company access to full-text versions of more than 18,000 journals. Using [[natural language processing]], Meta scans articles - as well as the millions of articles stored in open-access repositories - collecting information about authors, citations and topics. Participating publishers receive exposure for their journals in return.<ref name="twelve">{{citation|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2016/05/10/start-sees-data-analytics-information-overload-cure-researchers-publishers/|title=Predictive Analytics for Publishing|publisher=Inside Higher Ed|author=Carl Straumsheim|date=May 10, 2016|accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref> These include the [[American Medical Association]], [[BioMed Central]], [[Elsevier]], [[Karger]], [[Sage Publishing]], [[Taylor & Francis]], [[Wolters Kluwer]], and the [[Royal Society]].<ref name="thirteen">{{citation|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/digital/content-and-e-books/article/70118-digital-solutions-in-india-2016-big-data-and-ai-with-meta.html|title=Digital Solutions in India 2016: Big Data and AI with Meta|publisher=Publishers Weekly|author=Teri Tan|date=April 29, 2016|accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref><ref name="fourteen">{{citation|url=http://meta.com/partners|title=Partners|publisher=Meta|date=September 12, 2016|accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref> The technology for the platform was developed via a joint partnership between Meta and SRI International.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2017/01/25/chan-zuckerberg-initiative-meta-ai.html|title=Chan Zuckerberg Initiative makes first buy, a Canadian artificial intelligence startup |website=www.bizjournals.com |date=January 26, 2017 |access-date=2018-03-16}}</ref>
==Features and specifications== Meta includes coverage of the biomedical sciences with real-time updates from [[PubMed]] and other sources.<ref name="one" /><ref name="five">{{citation|url=http://sciencescape.org/under-the-hood|title=Under The Hood|publisher=Sciencescape.org|author=|date=|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name="six">{{citation|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/13/extreme-startups-demo-day-wrap-up-canadian-startups-make-a-strong-showing/|title=Extreme Startups Demo Day Wrap Up: Canadian Startups Make A Strong Showing|publisher=TechCrunch|author=Darrell Etherington|date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref> The website provides access to over 22 million papers with publication dates as early as the 1800s.<ref name="seven">{{citation|url=http://hazmanlabs.com/blog/2013/06/sciencescape-a-new-kid-on-the-block/|title=Sciencescape -- A new kid on the block|publisher=Hazman Labs, inc|author=Hazman Aziz|date=June 26, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703144352/http://hazmanlabs.com/blog/2013/06/sciencescape-a-new-kid-on-the-block/|archivedate=July 3, 2013|df=}}</ref><ref name="eight">{{citation|url=http://technogiants.net/2013/06/sciencescape-in-the-future-of-scientific-research/ |title=Sciencescape in the Future of Scientific Research|publisher=TechnoGiants|author=Vaibhav|date=June 18, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref> By sifting through papers and learning from user behavior, the service pinpoints key pieces of research and provides relevant search results.<ref name="two" /> Meta also provides visualizations about a field of research by organizing papers by their date of publication and citation count and then presenting the information in a way that allows users to quickly identify key historical papers.<ref name="four" />
The Meta Science research platform uses algorithms that allow users to sort new publications according to subject matter.<ref name="one" /> Users can subscribe to feeds for areas of research including [[biology]], [[genes]], [[diseases]], [[genetic disorders]], [[drugs]], people, labs & institutes, and [[Academic journals|journals]].<ref name="one" /><ref name="nine">{{citation|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2013/06/13/tech-companies-make-final-pitches-at-extreme-startups-2013-demo-day/|title=Tech companies make final pitches at Extreme Startups 2013 demo day|publisher=Financial Post|author=Mashoka Maimona|date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name="five" />
==Merge with Chan Zuckerberg Initiative== Meta merged with the [[Chan Zuckerberg Initiative]] in 2017, marking the Initiative's first acquisition.<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://meta.com}} {{Online social networking}}

revision.comment: Michele Weiner-Davis is no longer an NBCC approved Continuing Education Provider
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Michele Weiner-Davis |image = Michele Weiner-Davis.jpg |caption = Michele Weiner-Davis in 2007 |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |death_date = |death_place = |known_for = [[Solution focused brief therapy]], [[Divorce Busting]] |education = [[Grinnell College]], [[University of Kansas]] |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = [[marriage therapist]], [[author]] |home_town = |website = [http://www.divorcebusting.com/ www.DivorceBusting.com] }} '''Michele Weiner-Davis''' is a licensed clinical social worker, marriage and family therapist<ref>{{Citation| last = Flanagan | first = Caitlin | author-link = Caitlin Flanagan | title = The Wifely Duty | newspaper = [[The Atlantic Monthly]] | pages = | year = 2003 | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200301/flanagan | accessdate =}}</ref> and author in the field of [[family therapy]]. She is frequently quoted in the media and has been interviewed on television news programs regarding divorce prevention.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Johnson | first = L. A. | title = I Do's & Don'ts: More couples look to pre-marriage prep to give unions a better chance | newspaper =[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date = February 21, 2007 | url = http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07052/763588-51.stm}}</ref> Weiner-Davis has often been referred to as ''The Divorce Buster''<ref name="watch">{{cite web | last = Donahue | first = Phil | authorlink = Phil Donahue | title = Phil Donahue television show appearance | work = | publisher = [[NBC Universal Television Group]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=st7lb6HfojM | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> after coining the term “divorce busting” at an [[American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy]] conference in 1989.<ref name="Bees">{{Cite news | last = Kelleher | first = Kathleen | title = Birds & Bees; Divorce Busters Can Help Rescue Struggling Relationships | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | location = Home Edition | pages = E.2 | date = June 25, 2001 | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/74643683.html?dids=74643683:74643683&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+25%2C+2001&author=KATHLEEN+KELLEHER&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Birds+%26+Bees%3B+Divorce+Busters+Can+Help+Rescue+Struggling+Relationships&pqatl=google }}</ref><ref name="Performance1">{{cite web | last = Newsome | first = William Sean | title = Solution-Focused Brief Therapy | work = Research on Social Work Practice 14(5):336–43. | publisher = [[Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention]] | year = 2004 | url = http://www.ojjdp.gov/mpg/Solution-Focused%20Brief%20Therapy-MPGProgramDetail-712.aspx }}</ref> She currently writes a regular column, ''Divorce Busting: Musings From an Unabashed Marriage Saver'' in ''[[Psychology Today]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | title = Divorce Busting musings from an unabashed marriage saver | work = [[Psychology Today]] | publisher = Sussex Publishers | url = http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/divorce-busting}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Sex-Starved Women: America's Best Kept Secret? | work = | publisher = The Huffington Post | date = 24 April 2008 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/04/24/sex-starved-women-america_n_98520.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Personal life== Weiner-Davis grew up in [[New York City]]<ref name="Hopefully">{{Cite news | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | title = Hopefully Ever After | publisher = Coalition for Marriage, Family and Couples Education | date = September 13, 2001 | url = http://lists101.his.com/pipermail/smartmarriages/2001-September/000771.html}}</ref> along with two brothers. She has described her young childhood as idyllic, similar to the "[[The Waltons|Walton Family]]".<ref name="Hopefully"/><ref name="Introduction">{{cite web | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | title = Introduction | work = eNotAlone.com | publisher = Jelsoft Enterprises Ltd. | year = 2001 | url = http://www.enotalone.com/article/5468.html }}</ref> During Weiner-Davis' senior year in high school, her parents divorced after twenty-three years of marriage.<ref name="Hopefully"/><ref name="Becoming">{{Cite news | last = Hall | first = Trish | title = Breaking Up Is Becoming Harder to Do | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = March 14, 1991 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/14/garden/breaking-up-is-becoming-harder-to-do.html?scp=5&sq=michele+weiner+davis&st=nyt}}</ref> Her mother had been speaking with a therapist for several years, and she had been advised by the therapist that the differences between her and her husband were irreconcilable.<ref name="Introduction"/><ref>{{Cite book | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | title = The Divorce Remedy: The Proven 7-Step Program for Saving Your Marriage | publisher = Simon & Schuster | date = August 2002 | location = [[Google Books]] | pages = chapter 1 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jKHy2l4ScQUC&pg=PT17 | isbn = 978-0-684-87325-1}}</ref> Because of her parents' divorce, and due to the fact that many family counselors considered divorce to be a therapeutic option as a first resort in the 1960s, Weiner-Davis became a believer in the sanctity of marriage and a champion for saving the relationships of others.<ref name="Menders">{{cite web | last = Schoenfeld | first = Elizabeth | title = Marriage Menders | publisher = Questia Media America | url = https://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=Ly2DCp94TwhvJMtBq1pL8LbL2W0SkmVVMyGtyVLz0RjRq2tmXKdj!-1632884101!-699586516?docId=5001629531 }}</ref><ref name="save">{{cite web | last = Molineux | first = J. Bailey | title = To Save Your Marriage | publisher = Divorce Interactive | url = http://www.divorceinteractive.com/save_marriage.asp}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Molineux | first = J. Bailey | title = Divorce Busting | work = SolveYourProblem | publisher = Launch 3 | date = December 18, 2002 | url = http://www.solveyourproblem.com/artman/publish/article_106.shtml }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis has two children, a son and a daughter, and has been married since 1977.<ref name="Hopefully"/><ref>{{Citation | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | title = Confessions Of a Mother in Mourning | publisher = Sussex Publishers | newspaper = [[Psychology Today]] | date = August 25, 2008 | url = http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/divorce-busting/200808/confessions-mother-in-mourning }}</ref>
==Career== Weiner-Davis received a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1973 from [[Grinnell College]].<ref name="Grinnell">{{Citation | last = Worster | first = Kate | title = Grinnell College presents Alumni Awards | newspaper = Grinnell College | date = July 27, 2006 | url = http://wm.grinnell.edu/cgi-bin/relish.dll/showrel?id=558&rDate=07/26/2007&dDate=7/27/2006 }}</ref> She then earned a [[Master of Social Work|Master's Degree in Social Work]] (MSW) in 1977 from the [[University of Kansas]].<ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | title = Social Work Day planned for April 19 | newspaper = University Relations | location = [[University of Kansas]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = April 5, 1996 | url = http://www.oread.ku.edu/Oread96/OreadApril5/page4/social.html | accessdate = }}</ref> She began her early career in private practice, counseling young couples with relationship issues. During this time in her career, she believed that a separation was inevitable if one spouse had pre-determined that they wanted a divorce. In those situations, Weiner-Davis would counsel the couples on how to make the divorce easier on the family.<ref name="Menders"/><ref name="Oprah1">{{cite web | title = Oprah television appearance | work = | publisher = King World Productions | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ulDJSgP4Vo | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
During the 1980s, while working with the ''McHenry County Youth Service Bureau'' in [[Woodstock, Illinois|Woodstock]], [[Illinois]],<ref name="journal">{{Citation | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | last2 = de Shazer | first2 = Steve | author2-link = Steve de Shazer | last3 = Gingerich | first3 = Wallace J. | author3-link = | title = Building on pretreatment change to construct the therapeutic solution: an exploratory study | newspaper = ''[[Journal of Marital & Family Therapy]]'' | pages = Volume 13, Issue 4, pp. 359–363 | date = October 1987 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/ | accessdate = }}</ref> she became involved with [[Steve de Shazer]] <ref>{{cite web | last = de Shazer | first = Steve | authorlink = Steve de Shazer | title = Steve de Shazer | work = Brief Family Therapy Center | publisher = Solution Focused Brief Therapy Association | url = http://www.sfbta.org/BFTC/Steve_de_Shazer.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> and [[Insoo Kim Berg]] <ref>{{cite web | last = Kim Berg | first = Insoo | authorlink = Insoo Kim Berg | title = Insoo Kim Berg | work = Brief Family Therapy Center | publisher = Solution Focused Brief Therapy Association | url = http://www.sfbta.org/BFTC/Insoo_Kim_Burg.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> and his team at [[Insoo Kim Berg#The Brief Family Therapy Center|The Brief Family Therapy Center]] in Milwaukee, [[Wisconsin]]. She was part of the group of researchers that made contributions in the field of [[psychotherapy]] to help develop what is known as [[Solution focused brief therapy|Solution Focused Brief Therapy]] (SFBT).<ref name="articles">{{Cite journal | last1 = Trepper | first1 = Terry S | last2 = Dolan | first2 = Yvonne | last3 = McCollum | first3 = Eric E | last4 = Nelson | first4 = Thorana | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Steve De Shazer and the future of solution-focused therapy | journal = [[Journal of Marital & Family Therapy]] | volume = 32 | issue = 2 | pages = 133–139 | publisher = | location = | date = April 2006 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/ | issn = | doi = 10.1111/j.1752-0606.2006.tb01595.x | id = | accessdate = | pmid=16676891}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Stalker | first1 = Carol A | last2 = Levene | first2 = Judith E | last3 = Coady | first3 = Nick F | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Solution-focused brief therapy--one model fits all | journal = Families in Society | volume = 80 | issue = 5 | page = 468 | publisher = | location = | date = 1 September 1999 | url = http://www.familiesinsociety.org/default.asp | issn = | doi =10.1606/1044-3894.1476 | id = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Master">{{Cite book | last1 = Kottler | first1 = Jeffrey A. | last2 = Carlson | first2 = Jon | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Bad Therapy: Master Therapists Share Their Worst Failures | publisher = Brunner-Routledge | year = 2003 | location = New York, New York | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QTFpiDpEAWwC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_navlinks_s#v=onepage&q=michele%20weiner%20davis&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-415-93322-3}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Bray | first1 = James H. | last2 = Stanton | first2 = Mark | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Wiley-Blackwell Handbook of Family Psychology | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell]] | year = 2009 | location = | pages = Chapter 14 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1A2cSnWRZT4C&pg=PT228 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-4051-6994-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = McKeel | first = A. Jay | authorlink = | title = A selected review of research of solution-focused brief therapy | work = | publisher = Solution-focused approaches Dr. Alasdair MacDonald | url = http://www.emeraldinsight.com/index.htm | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>McKeel, A.J.[http://www.emeraldinsight.com/Insight/ViewContentServlet;jsessionid=750BCA9920AF5A549518FE1C7E08249E?Filename=/published/emeraldfulltextarticle/pdf/1421040302_ref.html "A clinician's guide to research on Solution-focused Therapy"], in Miller, S.D., Hubble, M.A., Duncan, B.L. (Eds), ''Handbook of Solution-focused Brief Therapy'', Jossey-Bass, San Francisco, California, 1996.</ref>
During this period of her career, after her publications in the ''[[Journal of Marital & Family Therapy]]'', she wrote her first book on divorce prevention: ''[[Divorce Busting]]'', published in 1992. She opened her first Divorce Busting Center in Woodstock, Illinois. After moving to [[Boulder, Colorado]], she opened her second Divorce Busting Center where she continues to see individuals and couples as a marriage and family therapist.<ref name="Choice">{{cite web | last = Cottrill | first = Jeffrey | authorlink = | title = Is Divorce the Right Choice for You | work = | publisher = Divorce Magazine | url = http://www.divorcemag.com/articles/Relationships/choice.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Exclusive">{{cite web | last = de Bonvoisin | first = Ariane | authorlink = | title = Exclusive Interview Michele Weiner-Davis | work = | publisher = The First Thirty Days | url = http://www.first30days.com/experts/michele-weiner-davis | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> Weiner-Davis says her patients are usually out of therapy in about six visits, while many marriage therapies last months or years.<ref name="Savers">{{Citation | last = Corliss | first = Richard | author-link = | last2 = Steptoek | first2 = Sonja | author2-link = | title = The Marriage Savers | newspaper = Time magazine Asia | page = 3 | date = March 29, 2004 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,993151,00.html | accessdate = }}</ref> She advocates an action-based approach and asks each partner in a marriage to "provide what the other needs regardless of whether the giver understands it".<ref name="Savers"/> She launched an online marital support website, ''Divorcebusting.com'' in June 1998. It attracts thousands of people each day. Her free Open Messageboard [[web forums]]<ref>{{cite web | last = Holetzky | first = Sherry | authorlink = | title = Who Ya Gonna Call? Divorce Busters! | work = | publisher = Families.com | date = 6 Oct 2006 | url = http://marriage.families.com/blog/who-ya-gonna-call-divorce-busters | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> gives the public a place and a way to communicate with Weiner-Davis and has become a place of last resort for many couples before they end up in divorce court.<ref name="appetite">{{Citation | last = Kampert | first = Patrick | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Whetting your appetite for sex | newspaper = Chicago Tribune | pages = | date = February 3, 2003 | url = http://lists101.his.com/pipermail/smartmarriages/2003-January/001446.html | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Warren | first = Timothy | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = 'Can't afford' divorce in hard times | newspaper = [[The Washington Times]] | pages = | date = February 6, 2009 | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/feb/06/cant-afford-divorce-in-hard-time-couples-stick-tog/ | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Divorceproof">{{Citation |last=Cole |first=Diane |author-link= |last2= |first2= |author2-link= |title=Divorceproof Your Marriage |newspaper=U.S. News and World Report |pages= |date=December 17, 2006 |url=http://health.usnews.com/usnews/health/articles/061217/25divorce.family.htm |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091205202941/http://health.usnews.com/usnews/health/articles/061217/25divorce.family.htm |archivedate=2009-12-05 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Diary">{{Citation | last = Johnson | first = L. A. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = 'Diary of an Affair' | newspaper = Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | pages = | date = March 3, 2005 | url = http://www.pittsburghpostgazette.com/pg/05062/498908-237.stm | accessdate = }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis is a clinical member and approved supervisor for the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Michele Weiner-Davis, M.S.W., LCSW | work = | publisher = [[American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy]] | url = http://www.aamft.org/iMIS15/AAMFT/ | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Approved Continuing Education Providers | work = | publisher = National Board for certified Counselors | url = http://www.nbcc.org/directory/ListProviders.aspx | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Digiacinto, M.Ed., LPC | first = Glinda | authorlink = | title = Credentials | work = | publisher = Marriage Works | url = http://mckinneymarriageworks.com/credentials.htm | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> Therapists from many countries come to the U.S. for her professional training seminars and some of her books and publications based on (SFBT) are used by university professors and professional organizations for classroom and continuing education credits.<ref>{{Citation | last = Homrich | first = Alicia M. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = CPY 557 Couples and Marriage Therapy | place = Winter Park, FL | publisher = Rollins College | date = January 6 – April 21, 2003 | volume = | edition = Rollins College Graduate Studies in Counseling | page = | pages = | url = http://www.apa.org/divisions/div43/Syllabi/557HomrichSyllabus03.doc | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Gray | first = Dr. Edward | authorlink = | title = Marital Therapy 5752 | work = | publisher = Harding University Graduate School of Religion, Memphis, Tennessee | date = Fall 2007 | url = http://hst.edu/ | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Bohanon | first = Leonard M. | authorlink = | title = Psychology PSYC 8357 | work = | publisher = Our Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX | date = Fall 2009 | url = http://www.ollusa.edu/s/1190/start2012.aspx | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> She also works directly over the phone with couples from many countries including Hong Kong, Singapore, India and Japan.<ref name="Savers"/>
She is also involved in education and support in supplying advice for several online internet groups including ''[[Redbook]]'',<ref>{{cite web | last = Latvala | first = Charlotte | authorlink = | title = When Giving Up Is Good to Do | work = [[Redbook]] | url = http://www.redbookmag.com/health-wellness/advice/give-up-good-2 | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> Planet-Therapy.com,<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Contributing Educator | work = | publisher = Planet-Therapy | url = http://www.planet-therapy.com/pub/ed_about/index.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[IVillage]]'',<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = The Love Council | work = | publisher = ivillage.com | url = http://love.ivillage.com/authors/0,16009,2-6,00.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> and The National Registry of Marriage Friendly Therapists.<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Wenger | first1 = Kathleen S. | authorlink = | title = Distinguished Advisors | work = | publisher = The National Registry of Marriage Friendly Therapists | url = http://www.marriagefriendlytherapists.com/about.php | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis was a State-of-the-Art Faculty presenter in 2005 and in 2009 for the Evolution of Psychotherapy Conference that is held every five years by The Milton H Erickson Foundation.<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Evolution of Psychotherapy 2009 brochure | work = | publisher = Milton H Erickson Foundation | year = 2009 | url = http://www.gotomylist.com/jeffco/20040601/evolution%20brochure.pdf | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Evolution of Psychotherapy 2009 syllabus | work = | publisher = Milton H Erickson Foundation | year = 2009 | url = http://www.evolutionofpsychotherapy.com/syllabus.pdf | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Milton H Erickson Foundation Newsletter Conference Issue | work = Vol.25 #3 | publisher = Milton H Erickson Foundation | year = 2005 | url = http://www.evolutionofpsychotherapy.com/EP2009/ | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Tuchman | first = Gary | author-link = | last2 = Cooper | first2 = Anderson | author2-link = Anderson Cooper | title = Keeping Them Honest | place = | publisher = CNN | date = December 8, 2009 | volume = | edition = | page = | pages = | url = http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0912/08/acd.01.html | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref>
==Books== In 1989 Weiner-Davis co-authored her first book, ''In Search of Solutions'':''A New Direction in Psychotherapy'' with [[Bill O'Hanlon]].<ref name="abstract">{{Citation | last = Piercy | first = Fred P. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Book Review In search of solutions: A new direction in psychotherapy | journal = [[Journal of Marital & Family Therapy]] | volume = Volume 47 | issue = Issue 1 | pages = 97–106 | date = 8 Jun 2007 | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119352530/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0 | doi = | id = }}</ref> This book was aimed at practicing psychotherapists and based on the principles of [[Solution focused brief therapy]] (SFBT),<ref name="Performance2">{{cite web | last = Newsome | first = William Sean | title = Solution-Focused Brief Therapy | work = Research on Social Work Practice 14(5):336–43. | publisher = Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention | year = 2004 | url = http://www2.dsgonline.com/mpg/mpg_program_detail.aspx?ID=712&title=Solution-Focused%20Brief%20Therapy }}</ref> which is said to have derived in part from the influence and work of [[Milton H. Erickson]]<ref>{{Citation | last = Kerby | first = Dave | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Psychotherapy:Theory, Research, Practice, Training | journal = [[American Psychological Association]] | volume = Vol. 27 | issue = No. 4 | pages = 660–661 | year = 1990 | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/index.cfm?fa=buy.optionToBuy&id=2009-16524-001&CFID=5344214&CFTOKEN=88581288 | doi = | id = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Lynn | first1 = Steven J. | last2 = Rhue | first2 = Judith W. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Theories of Hypnosis:Current Models and Perspectives | publisher = [[Guilford Press]] | year = 1991 | location = New York,N.Y. | page = 292 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Ez7Nq80QMtoC&pg=PA292&lpg=PA292&ots=2PnQofbkzA&dq=Michele+Weiner+Davis+citatons&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-89862-343-7 }}</ref> and their research from the Brief Family Therapy Center. A revised second edition of the book ''In Search of Solutions'', which contained new material in the advances in the field of (SFBT), was re-released in 2003.<ref>{{Cite book | last = O'Hanlon | first = Bill | authorlink = Bill O'Hanlon |author2=Weiner-Davis,Michele | title = Book Details | publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]] | year = 1989 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books/about/In_Search_of_Solutions.html?id=5lc8X3AjPFEC | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-393-70061-9}}</ref>
After years of experience in private practice Weiner-Davis came to the conclusion that in many cases divorced couples were merely exchanging one set of problems for another.<ref>{{cite web | last = Condrell | first = Kenneth N. | authorlink = | title = Why Parents Should Think Twice | work = | publisher = Achieve Solutions | date = June 13, 2006 | url = https://www.achievesolutions.net/achievesolutions/en/ctbhp/Content.do?contentId=8286 | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> She desired to translate the principles of (SFBT) into everyday English and to spread the word of its effective use, believing that most marriages are worth saving and their problems solvable.<ref name="Choice"/> To accomplish this goal she wrote the self-help book ''[[Divorce Busting|Divorce Busting: A Step-By-Step Approach to Making Your Marriage Loving Again]]''.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Johnson | first = L.A. | title = I Do's & Don'ts: More couples look to pre-marriage prep to give unions a better chance | newspaper = | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | date = February 21, 2007 | url = http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07052/763588-51.stm | accessdate = }}</ref> The book challenged mainstream psychotherapeutic techniques at the time<ref name="Savers"/> and gave her national recognition as a notable therapist in [[family therapy]]. Weiner-Davis believed that far from the traditional fairy-tale notion of "happily ever after," successful marriages involve working through and surviving problems, setbacks, and conflicts to become stronger.<ref name="Choice"/> The core of the book's principles is that even if only one spouse desired to save the relationship or make a change, a marriage could be saved.
In 1996 Weiner-Davis released her third book, ''Change Your Life and Everyone In It'': ''How to''.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | authorlink = | title = Change Your Life and Everyone In It: How to | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1996 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Abz1DC1iVrYC&dq=Change+Your+Life+and+Everyone+In+It:+How+to.&cd=1 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-684-82469-7}}</ref> It was written in order to expand upon the other more personal issues outside of relationships that she believed an effective (SFBT) approach might be able to solve or help with. The book used real life case examples of past experiences she had seen during therapy over the years in helping others to deal with personal problems caused by [[stress (biology)|stress]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and [[anxiety]]. The book was originally released in 1995 with the title ''Fire Your Shrink!'' before being renamed.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Weiner-Davis | first = Michele | authorlink = | title = Fire Your Shrink! | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1995 | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1c9bPgAACAAJ&dq=Fire+Your+Shrink&cd=1 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-671-86755-3}}</ref><ref name="fire">{{Cite news | last = Bush | first = John | title = Therapist's Advice: Fire Shrink, Buy Book | newspaper = [[Chicago Tribune]] | location = Chicago, Illinois | page = 2 | language = | publisher = | date = February 7, 1995 | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-02-07/news/9502070168_1_clients-michele-weiner-davis-traditional-therapy | accessdate = }}</ref> She outlines techniques which break with traditional psychotherapy and focuses on finding solutions rather than root causes of problems.<ref name="fire" /> Weiner Davis said her practice focuses on the future rather than the past and commented that: "Analyzing the past can be enlightening and educational, but can be a complete waste of time....This should not be called psychotherapy. It's a process of change, not [[introspection]]".<ref name="fire" />
In 1999 Weiner-Davis wrote her 4th book ''Getting Through to the Man You Love'':''The No-Nonsense, No-Nagging Guide for Women''. This book was written for women in an attempt to help women get through to their spouse more effectively.<ref>{{cite web | last = McManus | first = Mike | authorlink = | title = Those threatened by divorce | work = | publisher = Marriage Savers | year = 2001 | url = http://www.preventingdivorce.com/marriage_savers__to.htm | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> The book was based on both personal experiences during therapy with women and the trend in [[divorce#Statistics|divorce]] rates that show women file for divorce two-thirds of the time.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Tierny | first = John | title = The Big City; A New Look At Realities Of Divorce | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = July 11, 2000 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/11/nyregion/the-big-city-a-new-look-at-realities-of-divorce.html?scp=1&sq=%22New%20Look%20at%20Realities%20of%20Divorce&st=cse | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Kuhn | first = Richard | author-link = | last2 = Guidubaldi | first2 = John | author2-link = | title = Child Custody Policies and Divorce Rates in the US | newspaper = [[Children's Rights Council]] | pages = | date = October 1997 | url = http://deltabravo.net/custody/divrates.php | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Ritter | first = Bill | authorlink = | title = Men After Divorce: In Touch With Feelings | work = | publisher = [[20/20 (US television show)|ABC News 20/20]] | date = March 13, 2009 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=132639&page=1 | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
In 2001 Weiner-Davis released a sequel to ''[[Divorce Busting]]'', ''The Divorce Remedy'':''The Proven 7-Step Program for Saving Your Marriage''.<ref name="save"/> After hearing from thousands of readers over the years who asked particular questions about their own marital circumstances, Weiner-Davis extracted the ideas from her experience and past books and then broke down the ideas into seven specific steps a person could follow. She also discusses some other key relationship issues such as [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[infidelity]], [[Internet addiction disorder|Internet obsession]], [[sexual problems]] & [[midlife crisis]].
In 2003 Weiner-Davis released her book ''The Sex-Starved Marriage'': ''A Couple's Guide to Boosting Their Marriage Libido''.<ref name="Savers"/> She found herself writing about this particular subject after she saw a pattern developing in her practice<ref name="appetite"/> and determined that a lack of physical intimacy between couples had been leading couples further apart.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Jensen | first = Peter | title = More sex means better sex, marriage therapist says | newspaper = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = April 27, 2003 | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2003-04-27/news/0304280378_1_desire-marriage-therapist-sex-starved-marriage | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="msn">{{cite web | last = Kotb | first = Hoda | authorlink = Hoda Kotb | title = You don’t have to be ‘The Sex-Starved Wife’ | work = [[MSNBC]] | publisher = [[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]] | date = Jan 7, 2008 | url = http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/22492002/ | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> The book was written in order to take a more proactive stance to help married couples achieve better relationships before their love fades.<ref name="appetite"/>
Her book ''The Sex-Starved Wife'': ''What to Do When He's Lost Desire'' was released in 2008. The book was undertaken after Weiner-Davis was inundated with telephone calls and letters from many women who said they were having this issue within their marriage and were seeking information to resolve the issue with their husbands.<ref>{{Citation | last = Klein | first = Christianne | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = The 'Sex-Starved Wives' Club | newspaper = [[Good Morning America]] | pages = | date = January 9, 2008 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=4107560 | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Wives">{{Citation | last = Sachs | first = Andrea | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Help for Sex-Starved Wives | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | pages = | date = April 7, 2008 | url = http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1728520,00.html | accessdate = }}</ref> To help determine the extent of the issue Weiner-Davis did a study with the help of ''[[Redbook]]'' which showed that two-thirds of the women who responded said they desired sex at least as much or more as their husbands did.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Cleaver | first = Samantha | title = 5 Ways to Reignite the Passion | newspaper = [[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health Magazine]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | url = https://secure.rodale.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/OaeEntryPage?storeId=10057&source=Rodale&mktOfferId=USD54635&keycode=I2EAA002 | accessdate = }} </ref>
Weiner-Davis' latest book ''Healing From Infidelity: The Divorce Busting Guide to Rebuilding Your Marriage After an Affair'' was released in January 2017. Due to the high percentage of couples in her practice who face betrayal, she developed a step-by-step program for rebuilding trust and reinventing couples' marriages. The book, though intended for the general public is considered a useful resource for the therapists who treat them.<ref name="Healing">{{Citation | last = Zeig | first = Jeffrey | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Healing from Infidelity | newspaper = The Milton H. Erickson Foundation Newsletter | pages = | date = December 1, 2016 | url = https://erickson-foundation.org/docs/Vol-36-No-3.pdf | accessdate = January 20, 2017 }}</ref>
==In mass media== Weiner-Davis made her first television appearance on the talk show ''[[Donahue]]'', reporting that 85% of the couples using the methods and advice of [[Solution focused brief therapy|Solution Focused Brief Therapy]] (SFBT) were leaving from her therapy with their marriages intact.<ref name="watch"/><ref>{{Cite news | last = Nordlinger | first = Pia | title = The Anti-Divorce Revolution: The Debate on Marriage Takes a Surprising Turn | newspaper = [[The Weekly Standard]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = March 2, 1998 | url = http://www.dadi.org/antirevo.htm | accessdate = }}</ref>
She also made two other guest appearances on the talk show ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', discussing how the innovative but simple methods of SFBT could save relationships and make marriages stronger, contending that a person did not need a degree in psychology in order to improve their marriage.<ref name="Oprah2">{{cite web | title = Michele Weiner Davis on Oprah | work = | publisher = [[King World Productions]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ulDJSgP4Vo | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
The success of Weiner-Davis last two books, ''The Sex-Starved Marriage'' and ''The Sex-Starved Wife'', led Weiner-Davis to appear on several television news programs including ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'',<ref name="msn"/><ref>{{cite web | last = Couric | first = Katie | authorlink = Katie Couric | title = The Future of Children | work = [[MSNBC]] | publisher = [[Today (NBC program)|Today]] | date = September 14, 2005 | url = https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:43ZP7VthLpMJ:futureofchildren.org/futureofchildren/press/news/news-091405.pdf+The+Future+of+Children+katie+couric&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESiJlpfsfBjiQ9dNP1UgdsoR-iW89oNaCr3VL1NlXrtvcj0mLzKgIr4_scBd0CjvoJBtK9P96nWlVSGUiCglf3MZMIqwdANwDNlNE8VpEFRibqHzIOH0SOWjlinn2j7wwhnOmZtM&sig=AHIEtbRmYXFkKS4neLwuQvRz6aBPED5gRw | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Reichman | first = Judith | authorlink = | title = Why is your marriage sexless? | work = MSNBC | publisher = [[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]] | date = Jan 7, 2008 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WcZDh90I5ZY | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[20/20 (US television show)|ABC News 20/20]]'',<ref>{{cite web | last = Stossel | first = John F. | authorlink = John F. Stossel | title = Advice on the Sexless Marriage | work = [[20/20 (US television show)|ABC News 20/20]] | date = September 29, 2003 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=123647&page=1 | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Stossel | first = John F. | authorlink = John F. Stossel | title = Advice on the Sexless Marriage | work= ABC News 20/20 | date = September 29, 2003 | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfZVg2RWHhY | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[The Early Show|The CBS Early Show]]'',<ref>{{cite web | last = Neal | first = Rome | authorlink = |author2=Syler Rene | title = Bring The Sex Back Into Marriage | work = [[The Early Show|The CBS Early Show]] | date = 4 November 2003 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/11/03/earlyshow/living/main581561.shtml | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'',<ref>{{cite web | last = O'Reilly | first = Bill | authorlink = Bill O'Reilly (political commentator) | title = Sex Starved Marriage | work = [[The O'Reilly Factor]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MY8ZkVSKNYM | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> and ''[[PBS]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last = Sirott | first = Bob | authorlink = Bob Sirott | title = Interview Michele Weiner-Davis | work = | publisher = [[PBS]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJSd-Hy0uII | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
Over the span of her career Weiner-Davis has been interviewed and referred to in newspaper and magazine articles including ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name="Becoming"/><ref>{{Citation | last = Butler | first = Katy | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Many Couples Must Negotiate Terms of 'Brokeback' Marriages | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | pages = | date = March 7, 2006 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/07/health/07broke.html?_r=1&scp=2&sq=michele+weiner+davis&st=nyt | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'',<ref name="Savers"/><ref name="Wives"/> ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref name="Bees"/> ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'',<ref name="appetite"/> ''[[Newsweek]]'',<ref>{{Citation | last = Deveny | first = Kathleen | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Were Not in the mood | newspaper = [[Newsweek]] | pages = | date = June 30, 2003 | url = http://www.newsweek.com/id/59769 | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Raymond | first = Joan | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = She’s Gotta Have It | newspaper = [[Newsweek]] | pages = | date = Jan 4, 2008 | url = http://www.newsweek.com/id/84397 | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'',<ref>{{Citation | last = Peterson | first = Karen S. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = When 'I do' becomes 'I don't want to' | newspaper = [[USA Today]] | pages = |date=2003-01-21 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2003-01-21-lustless-usat_x.htm | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Jayson | first = Sharon | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = What kills sex in a marriage?Look past the stereotypes | newspaper = [[USA Today]] | pages = | date = 6 January 2008 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2008-01-06-sex-marriage_N.htm | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'',<ref>{{Citation | last = Benjamin | first = Jennifer | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Great Relationship but Sucky Sex? | work = [[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]] | pages = | url = http://www.cosmopolitan.com/sex-love/tips-moves/great-relationship-but-sucky-sex-0709?click=main_sr | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'',<ref>{{Citation | last = Goldiner | first = Dave | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Married women faithful to infidelity | newspaper = [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] | pages = | date = July 5, 2004 | url = http://articles.nydailynews.com/2004-07-05/news/18271177_1_infidelity-record-pace-therapist | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[The Washington Times]]'',<ref name="free">{{Citation | last = Toto | first = Christian | author-link = | last2 = Ward | first2 = Jon | author2-link = | title = For 25 years, a paper to stand 'for free people' | newspaper = [[The Washington Times]] | pages = | date = May 18, 2007 | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2007/may/18/20070518-124105-7436r/ | accessdate = }}</ref><ref name="Buster">{{Citation | last = Wetzstein | first = Cheryl | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Divorce Buster | newspaper = [[The Washington Times]] | pages = | date = May 15, 2007 | url = http://lists101.his.com/pipermail/smartmarriages/2007-May/003405.html | accessdate = }}</ref> ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''.<ref name="Divorceproof"/>
Weiner-Davis has also been involved in a reality based show for the [[BBC]] about helping couples save their marriages.<ref name="Diary"/><ref>{{Cite news | last = | first = | title = BBC Seeks Out Rocky Relationships | newspaper = [[Wave of Long Island|Wave of Long Island Newspaper]] | location = [[Rockaway, Queens|Rockaway]], [[Queens]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | pages = | language = | publisher = Wave Publishing Co. | date = August 18, 2005 | url = http://www.rockawave.com/news/2005/0818/Community/010.html | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Recognition== Weiner-Davis, along with 21 other American therapists, was profiled in the 2003 book ''Bad Therapy: Master Therapists Share Their Worst Failures'' by Jeffrey Kottler and Jon Carlson. In it Weiner-Davis describes how she could sometimes tend to focus more on technique as a young therapist and then how she eventually learned from those experiences with couples how to become a better therapist.<ref>{{cite book | last = Kottler | first = Jeffrey A | authorlink = |author2=Jon Carlson | title = Bad Therapy: Master Therapists Share Their Worst Failures | publisher = Brunner Routledge | series = | volume = | edition = | location = | pages = | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books/about/Bad_Therapy.html?id=QTFpiDpEAWwC | doi = | id = | isbn = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis received an award for Outstanding Contribution to Marriage and Family Therapy in 2001 from The [[American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy]], which represents the professional interests of more than 24,000 marriage and family therapists throughout the United States, Canada and abroad.<ref>American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy [http://www.aamft.org/imis15/Content/About_AAMFT/Award_Recipents.aspx Outstanding Contribution to Marriage and Family Therapy], AAMFT Award Recipients 2001 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314094922/http://www.aamft.org/imis15/Content/About_AAMFT/Award_Recipents.aspx |date=March 14, 2012 }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis received an Impact Award during the 7th Annual Smart Marriages Conference (The Coalition for Marriage, Family, and Couples Education) in 2003. According to their website, "the Impact Awards are presented to those whose research, books, political or grassroots action, leadership and brilliant reconceptualizations have given us new hope about reversing the epidemic of divorce and family breakdown".<ref>{{cite web | last = Sollee | first = Diane | authorlink = | title = Impact Awards | work = | publisher = Coalition for Marriage, Family and Couples Education | year = 2003 | url = http://www.smartmarriages.com/impact.awards.html | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref>
Weiner-Davis received ''The Washington Times'' Inaugural Founding Spirit Award in 2007 recognizing her work in community activism.<ref name="free"/><ref name="Buster"/>
<ref>Eyes of a Woman [http://www.eyesofawoman.com/relationship/surviving-a-sexless-marriage/ Surviving Sexless Marriage] </ref>

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=March 2010}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2010}} }}
{{Infobox journal | title = Music Survey | cover = | editor = | discipline = [[Music]] | former_names = | abbreviation = | publisher = | country = United Kingdom | frequency = | history = 1947-1952 | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = }} '''''Music Survey''''' was a short-lived [[academic journal]] covering [[classical music|classical]] and [[contemporary classical music|contemporary music]], which flourished in the [[United Kingdom]] for a brief period after [[World War II]]. Though it was published for only five years and in that time had only a small circulation, it had a remarkable impact on British musical and musicological life in the 1950s, and was instrumental in providing a home for the time's pro-[[Benjamin Britten]] and pro-[[Arnold Schoenberg]] writing, as well as launching the critical and editorial careers of [[Donald Mitchell (writer)|Donald Mitchell]] and [[Hans Keller]].
The journal was established in 1947, while Mitchell was a teacher at Oakfield School, Dulwich, South London, by the headmaster W.W. (David) Livingston. Keller joined him as co-editor in 1949, when the journal was re-launched in the form of the so-called 'New Series'. Several articles were written by prominent composers such as [[Luigi Dallapiccola]], [[Mátyás Seiber]], and [[Robert Simpson (composer)|Robert Simpson]].
''Music Survey'' ceased publication in 1952; in 1981 a single-volume reprint of the 'New Series' was produced.
==Bibliography== * ''Music Survey: New Series, 1949-52''. Collected reprint (1 volume; Faber and Faber, London) 1981.
[[Category:Music journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1947]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1952]] [[Category:English-language journals]] [[Category:1947 establishments in the United Kingdom]]
